I can't help but smile when I think about it. When the betrayal happened, I knew the world had to see the truth. I wasn't going to let them rewrite the story. So I gathered all the evidence—screenshots, messages, and, of course, the photos we'd once shared in private. It was beautiful how quickly it all spread. People started to ask questions, to doubt what they’d believed. They saw the real side of things, the side that wasn't so polished. 

I made sure to post it all in a way that couldn’t be ignored—on every platform they were on, tagged in their friends, their family. I wanted them to feel the weight of their own shame. And it worked. They tried to delete everything, but it was too late. The damage was done. People started to distance themselves. They realized the truth isn’t always what it seems.

It was a harsh lesson for everyone involved, but I think it was necessary. Sometimes, the only way to stop someone from hurting others is to show them what they’re really made of. And let’s be honest, they got what was coming to them.
